conclusion: Break down the problem considering both particles one at a time.
Determine velocity v for the first particle using qE = qvB, resulting in v = E/B.
Calculate kinetic energy Ek1 for the first particle as Ek1 = 1/2 mv^2, substituting v = E/B.
Express kinetic energy in terms of potential energy U: qU = 1/2 m (E^2/B^2), resulting in U = mE^2/(2qB^2).
Apply the same potential difference U to the second particle with mass 2m and charge q.
Determine velocity v' for the second particle using v' = sqrt(qU/m), resulting in v' = E/(sqrt(2)B).
Calculate electric force Fe = qE and magnetic force Fm = qv'B for the second particle, resulting in Fm = qE/sqrt(2).
Determine net force Fnet = Fe - Fm, resulting in Fnet = qE(sqrt(2) - 1)/sqrt(2).
Assume a small distance L through which the second particle travels in N.
Calculate acceleration a = Fnet/(2m), resulting in a = qE(sqrt(2) - 1)/(2sqrt(2)m).
Determine time t = L/v', resulting in t = L sqrt(2)B/E.
Calculate deviation d using d = 1/2 at^2, resulting in d = qEL^2(sqrt(2) - 1)B^2/(4mE^2).
Determine kinetic energy Ek for the second particle as Ek = 1/2(2m)v'^2, resulting in Ek = mE^2/(2B^2).
Final kinetic energy of the second particle is mE^2/(2B^2).
